chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Dose
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Adults and children older than 10 years of age — 250 mg to 500 mg, four times a day for 7 days.
  • Children 2–9 years of age — 125 mg to 250 mg, four times a day for 7 days.
  • Children 1 month to 1 year of age — 62.5 mg to 125 mg, four times a day for 7 days.
    • Oral flucloxacillin is available as 250 mg and 500 mg capsules, and 125 mg per 5 mL and 250 mg per 5 mL oral solution.
  • The recommendations on length of antibiotics course are extrapolated from an antibiotics guideline produced by Public Health England (PHE) [PHE, 2017].
    • PHE did not consider the treatment of acute paronychia but for other bacterial skin infections, such as impetigo and cellulitis, they recommend a duration of 7 days for empirical antibiotic treatment [PHE, 2017].
  • CKS found no randomized controlled trials that studied the effectiveness of antibiotic treatment (or the length of antibiotic course needed) for the treatment of acute paronychia.

[BNF 73, 2017]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Adverse effects
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Common adverse effects of flucloxacillin include:
    • Gastrointestinal disturbances.
    • Joint pains.
    • Serum sickness-like reaction.
    • Allergic reactions such as rashes and anaphylaxis occur in 1–10% of people treated with penicillins.
  • Other adverse effects include:
    • Antibiotic-associated colitis.
    • Cholestatic jaundice and hepatitis occurs very rarely up to several weeks after treatment with flucloxacillin has been stopped. Administration for more than 2 weeks and increasing age are risk factors.
    • Cerebral irritation, CNS toxicity, encephalopathy.
    • Coagulation disorders.
    • Haemolytic anaemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia.
    • Interstitial nephritis.

[ABPI, 2015a; BNF 73, 2017]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Contraindications and cautions
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Do not prescribe flucloxacillin to people with:
    • A history of hypersensitivity (including anaphylaxis, urticaria or rash immediately after administration) to beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillins or cephalosporins.
    • A history of flucloxacillin-associated jaundice or hepatic dysfunction.
  • Prescribe flucloxacillin with caution to people with:
    • Hepatic dysfunction (not flucloxacillin related), especially if they are 50 years or over, or have a serious underlying disease.

[ABPI, 2015a; BNF 73, 2017; CSM, 2004a]

Drug interactions with flucloxacillin include:

  • Food — flucloxacillin should be taken one hour before food or on an empty stomach.
  • Anticoagulants such as warfarin — monitor INR so that changes in anticoagulant effects can be identified and corrected.
  • Methotrexate — consider monitoring as there have been rare reports of reduced clearance and acute methotrexate toxicity with concurrent use. One recommended approach is to carry out twice-weekly platelet and white cell count for 2 weeks initially and measure methotrexate levels if toxicity is suspected.
  • Oral hormonal contraception — additional contraceptive precautions are not required during or after courses of flucloxacillin.
    • However, women should be advised about the importance of correct contraceptive practice if they experience vomiting or diarrhoea.

[Preston, 2016; FSRH, 2017]
